Identifies the trigger event that occurred.
This is mandatory because it is essential to understanding the meaning of the event.
Describes the status of the control act, which is always complete (it happened).
Required for completeness of specification.
Indicates the time the event (e.g. query, change, activation) should begin and occasionally when it should end.

The time an event becomes effective may differ from the time the event is recorded (i.e. it may be in the future or the past). For events such as 'suspend', an intended end date may also be indicated.
Identifies why this specific message interaction (e.g. query, activation request, modification request) occurred.
The domain associated with this attribute will vary for each interaction and will be noted as part of the interaction description.
Allows identifying a reason for a specific action, such as 'reason for hold' or 'reason for accessing information'.

Indicates the person responsible for entering the query into the system. Used when different from the person responsible for the request (author). For example, physician requests administrative assistant to print off a patient's medication profile.
This should only be specified if different from the author.
Important for audit information and determining permissions.
The association is optional because in some jurisdictions this information will be conveyed as part of the authentication token.
Indicates the location where the record of this event was entered.
This should only be specified if different from the location where the event was authored.
Indicates a potential location for written records, and may also be important for authentication purposes.
The association is optional because in some jurisdictions this information will be conveyed as part of the authentication token.
Indicates the service delivery location where the event occurred.
Indicates where paper records may be located, and may be important to determining authorization.
The association is optional because in some jurisdictions this information will be conveyed as part of the authentication token.
Identifies the authentication token that references information about the people and/or places responsible for the event.
Some systems perform centralized authentication of providers and/or locations. The association is optional because not all systems will make use of a token-based authentication process.
Class which describes the query specifics and parameter list.
Unique number for this particular query.
Needed to allow continuation of queries and linking of query requests and responses and therefore mandatory.
This allows the sender to indicate to the receiver that this query should follow an expedited processing flow.

Intended to convey the requested 'packaging' of query results. This attribute does not affect which rows are selected by the query, just the manner in which they are returned. For example, a batch file containing responses, a response message containing multiple payloads, or a stream of response messages (notifications) each identifying itself as a response to a query request.
The number of response item repetitions that should be included in the initial response.

If not specified, the default behavior is to return all repetitions. However the recipient of a query may always choose to limit the quantity returned to be less than the number requested. Regardless of the number specified here, the number of rows returned will never exceed the number of matching rows based on the query parameters.
There may be a very large number of matching rows. To manage communication bandwidth, a limited set may initially be returned with further data retrieved by using query continuations.
Defines the units associated with the magnitude of the maximum size limit of a query response that can be accepted by the requesting application.
Needed to quantify the types of records requested to be returned in the query.
Allows for the trail of responsibility for the action. The association is optional because in some jurisdictions, the supervisor may be conveyed by he authentication token.
Important for audit information and determining permissions.
The association is optional because in some jurisdictions this information will be conveyed as part of the authentication token
Holds specification of sort order for instance matches to a query.
Optional for systems which can receive query requests and sort the results before returning to the query requestor.
When more than one sort control is specified, this is the order of this sort element amongst the others.
This number determines which sort element is using primarily, secondary, etc. and is therefore mandatory.
Name of the element to sort.
The name of the element is mandatory.
Sets the ascending or descending nature of the sort request.
This element is required.
Information pertaining to a client's agreement/acceptance to have his/her client identification and demographic information electronically stored and shared.

This will usually only be populated for queries, but could be used for updates if a jurisdiction requires consent before recording information in the EHR (e.g. consent to participate in electronic data exchange).
Note: keywords canot be passed from one application to another via the EHR (e.g. prescriber to dispenser via a Drug Information System).
Provides authorization to record and/or view client information.

Indicates the consent or keyword used to authorize access or update, including a reason for access; May also be used to override access restriction to the information ('break the glass') on a message by message basis.
This is the list of clinical and business issues that have been detected and/or managed involving the current action.
Any trigger event can result in errors or may allow for errors to be overridden or managed.
The Organization responsible for issuing the Other ID identified in the OtherIDs Role Class
Supports the requirement to supply additional information regarding the assigning Organization of the OtherID
An HL7 defined value representing the class or category that the Entity instance represents.
Examples: Person, Animal, Chemical Substance, Group, Organization

Due to the extremely large number of potential values for a code set representing all physical things in the universe, the class code indicates both the subtype branch of the Entity hierarchy used as well as a high level classifier to represent the instance of Entity. This can be used to constrain the eligible value domains for the Entity.code attribute.
An HL7 defined value representing whether the Entity represents a kind-of or a specific instance.
Examples: 1 human being (an instance), 3 syringes (quantified kind) or the population of Indianapolis (kind of group)

An Entity may at times represent information concerning a specific instance (the most common), a quantifiable group with common characteristics or a general type of Entity. This code distinguishes these different representations.
Unique identifier for the organization that assigned the non-healthcare identifier for the client.
Mandatory attribute supports the identification of the organization assigning the identifier to the client
A name for the non-healthcare organization
Populated attribute supports the identification of the organization assigning the identifier to the client

The IdentifiedEntity class is the entry point to the R-MIM and contains one or more identifiers (for example an "internal" id used only by computer systems and an "external" id for display to users) for the Person in the Client Registry. The statusCode is set to "active". The beginning of the effectiveTime is when the record was added to the registry.
Provides the message entry point required to add a person to the Client Registry
A code specifying the major category of the Identified Entity Role as defined by HL7 vocabulary.
http://www.hl7.org/v3ballot/html/infrastructure/vocabulary/RoleClass.htm
Provides a means to identify Roles played by entities
This identification attribute supports capture of a healthcare identifier specific to the client. This identifier may be assigned jurisdictionally or by care facility.
At least 1 client identifier must be present in the message
Populated attribute supports unique identification of the client.
Indicates the status of the Client role (e.g. Active)
Populated attribute supports the identification of the client
Indicates the effective time of the Client role;
Required attribute supports the identification of the client
A code that controls the disclosure of information about this client record.

Data in the EHR may at some point (and in some jurisdictions) be accessed directly by patients. Some health information may be deemed inappropriate for direct access by patients and requires interpretation by a clinician (e.g. prescription of placebos, analysis of certain psychiatric conditions, etc) Even where direct access by patient is not provided, there may need to be guidance to other providers viewing the record where care should be used in disclosing information to the patient. Non-clinical data (e.g. demographics) may need to be flagged as not for disclosure to patient and or next of kin. There may be professional policy and or legislative guidelines about when/if records may be flagged as not for direct disclosure.
Populated attribute supports the business requirement to provide restricted access where required
Information about what language(s) should be used to communicate with the focal person can be sent in the LanguageCommunication class.
Supports the business requirement to identify languages used by client for the purposes of communication
A code indicating the language of communication
Mandatory attribute conveying the expected language message elements are to be transmitted in.
Indicates the preferred language for all communications.
Required attribute that supports the business requirement to indicate the preferred language for all communications.
Identifiers used for the focal person by other organizations are sent in the OtherIDs class. The other organization can be sent in the E_Organization Entity Class
Provides the ability to capture additional client identifiers that are not healthcare specific
A code specifying the major category of a Role as defined by HL7 vocabulary.
http://www.hl7.org/v3ballot/html/infrastructure/vocabulary/RoleClass.htm
Provides a means to identify Roles played by entities
Other non-healthcare identifiers for the Client (e.g. Passport, SIN, DND, DIAND, Drivers License)
Mandatory attribute supports the identification of the client
A pan Canadian code further specifying the kind of Role such as Drivers License, RCMP, DND, Social Insurance Number
Populated attribute supports the identification of the client

The Parent Person class can send the person that is legally responsible for the care and management of the focal person. If the relationship (e.g., parent, spouse, unrelated friend) of the guardian to the focal person is of interest then a PersonalRelationship with the same persons as player and scoper should also be sent.
Supports the business requirement to capture identification and demographic information regarding the Identified Client's Next of Kin
An HL7 defined value representing the class or category that the Entity instance represents.
Examples: Person, Animal, Chemical Substance, Group, Organization
http://www.hl7.org/v3ballot/html/infrastructure/vocabulary/EntityClass.htm

Due to the extremely large number of potential values for a code set representing all physical things in the universe, the class code indicates both the subtype branch of the Entity hierarchy used as well as a high level classifier to represent the instance of Entity. This can be used to constrain the eligible value domains for the Entity.code attribute.

An HL7 defined value representing whether the Entity represents a kind-of or a specific instance. Examples: 1 human being (an instance), 3 syringes (quantified kind) or the population of Indianapolis (kind of group
http://www.hl7.org/v3ballot/html/infrastructure/vocabulary/EntityDeterminer.htm

An Entity may at times represent information concerning a specific instance (the most common), a quantifiable group with common characteristics or a general type of Entity. This code distinguishes these different representations.
A unique identifier for the next of kin
Mandatory attribute supports the identification of the next of kin
A name for the next of kin
Required attribute supports the identification of the next of kin
The Person class contains identifying and demographic data elements for the focal person similar to those in the HL7 v2.x PID segment such as name, gender, date of birth, deceased indicator and time.
Provides additional demographic data elements for the focal class IdentifiedEntity
In addition to IdentifiedEntity.ID two of the following three attributes must be provided to add a client Person.name, Person.administrativeGenderCode, and/or Person.birthTime
An HL7 defined value representing the class or category that the Entity instance represents. Examples: Person, Animal, Chemical Substance, Group, Organization
http://www.hl7.org/v3ballot/html/infrastructure/vocabulary/EntityClass.htm

Due to the extremely large number of potential values for a code set representing all physical things in the universe, the class code indicates both the subtype branch of the Entity hierarchy used as well as a high level classifier to represent the instance of Entity. Examples: 1 human being (an instance), 3 syringes (quantified kind) or the population of Indianapolis (kind of group)
http://www.hl7.org/v3ballot/html/infrastructure/vocabulary/EntityDeterminer.htm

An Entity may at times represent information concerning a specific instance (the most common), a quantifiable group with common characteristics or a general type of Entity. This code distinguishes these different representations.
Name(s) for the Client
Populated attribute supports the identification of the client
Provides information about telecom
Required attribute supports the identification of the client
Gender of the Client, this is not to be confused with Clinical Gender of a client. Administrative Gender is typically restricted to Male (M), Female (F) or Undifferentiated (U)
Populated attribute supports the identification of the client
Date of birth of the Client
Populated attribute supports the identification of the client
An indication that the client is deceased.
Required attribute supports the identification of the client
The date and time that a client's death occurred
Required attribute supports verification of death from official source such as Vital Statistics.
Deceased time only present if deceasedInd is = TRUE
An indication as to whether the client is part of a multiple birth.
Required attribute supports the identification of the client
The order in which this client was born if part of a multiple birth.
Required attribute supports the identification of the client
Address(es) of the Client
Populated attribute supports the identification of the client

Associations between persons in the Person Registry, such as spouse or parent, can be sent in a PersonalRelationship class. The exact nature of a association is described by the code attribute with a value drawn from the PersonalRelationshipRoleType domain. Most associations can be represented in either of two ways depending on who is the player and who is the scoper. For example, the association between a father and his daughter can be represented by a code of "father" where the parent is the player and the child is the scoper, or by a code of "daughter" where the child is the player and the parent is the scoper.
Supports the business requirement to capture additional information about the Identified Client's Next of Kin
A code specifying the major category of a Role as defined by HL7 vocabulary.

Links two people in a personal relationship. The character of the relationship must be defined by a PersonalRelationshipRoleType code. The player and scoper are determined by PersonalRelationshipRoleType code as well.
Provides a means to identify Roles played by entities
A code further specifying the kind of Role such as Mother, Father, Natural Parent or Step Parent
Mandatory attribute that supports understanding the relationship between the client and the ParentClient
The Organization responsible for issuing the Other ID identified in the OtherIDs Role Class
Supports the requirement to supply additional information regarding the assigning Organization of the OtherID

Data in the EHR may at some Data in the EHR may at some point (and in some jurisdictions) be accessed directly by patients. Some health information may be deemed inappropriate for direct access by patients and requires interpretation by a clinician (e.g. prescription of placebos, analysis of certain psychiatric conditions, etc) Even where direct access by patient is not provided, there may need to be guidance to other providers viewing the record where care should be used in disclosing information to the patient. Non-clinical data (e.g. demographics) may need to be flagged as not for disclosure to patient and or next of kin. There may be professional policy and or legislative guidelines about when/if records may be flagged as not for direct disclosure.
Populated attribute supports the business requirement to provide restricted access where required

Associations between persons in the Person Registry, such as spouse or parent, can be sent in a PersonalRelationship class. The exact nature of a association is described by the code attribute with a value drawn from the PersonalRelationshipRoleType domain. Most associations can be represented in either of two ways depending on who is the player and who is the scoper. For example, the association between a father and his daughter can be represented by a code of "father" where the parent is the player and the child is the scoper, or by a code of "daughter" where the child is the player and the parent is the scoper.
Supports the business requirement to capture additional information about the Identified Client's Next of Kin
A code specifying the major category of a Role as defined by HL7 vocabulary.

Links two people in a personal relationship. The character of the relationship must be defined by a PersonalRelationshipRoleType code. The player and scoper are determined by PersonalRelationshipRoleType code as well.

A record of something that is being done, has been done, can be done, or is intended or requested to be done. Acts connect to Entities in their Roles through Participations and connect to other Acts through ActRelationships. Participations are the authors, performers and other responsible parties as well as subjects and beneficiaries (which includes tools and material used in the performance of the act, which are also subjects). The moodCode distinguishes between Acts that are meant as factual records, vs. records of intended or ordered services, and the other modalities in which act can appear.

Acts are the pivot of the RIM; all domain information and processes are represented primarily in Acts. Any profession or business, including healthcare, is primarily constituted of intentional and occasionally non-intentional actions, performed and recorded by responsible actors. An Act-instance is a record of such an action.

The role class, assigned entity, captures the critical information of the provider playing the role of interest. This includes an identifier for the role, mailing address, phone number, and the time within which the role is played (may be open ended). The scoping organization, which may be omitted if not needed, provides the organizational context for the entity that actually plays the role. For example, the role scoper will normally be the party that assigns the identifier for the role.

A role played by a place at which services may be provided. The RIM defines two specializations of service delivery location: 1. incidental service delivery location - A role played by a place at which health care services may be provided without prior designation or authorization and 2. dedicated service delivery location - A role played by a place that is intended to house the provision of services. Scoper is the Entity (typically Organization) that provides these services. This is not synonymous with "ownership". This can be further characterized by a role code of: A)DedicatedClinicalLocationRoleType - A role of a place that further classifies the clinical setting (e.g., cardiology clinic, primary care clinic, rehabilitation hospital, skilled nursing facility) in which care is delivered during an encounter or B)DedicatedNonClinicalLocationRoleType - A role of a place that further classifies the setting in which non-clinical services are delivered. A given physical place can play multiple service delivery location roles each with its own attributes. For example, a Podiatric clinic and Research clinic may meet on alternate days in the same physical location; each clinic uses its own mailing address and telephone number.
Roleclass required to support the identification of the physical location where healthcare services are provided

Data in the EHR may at some point (and in some jurisdictions) be accessed directly by patients. Some health information may be deemed inappropriate for direct access by patients and requires interpretation by a clinician (e.g. prescription of placebos, analysis of certain psychiatric conditions, etc) Even where direct access by patient is not provided, there may need to be guidance to other providers viewing the record where care should be used in disclosing information to the patient. Non-clinical data (e.g. demographics) may need to be flagged as not for disclosure to patient and or next of kin. There may be professional policy and or legislative guidelines about when/if records may be flagged as not for direct disclosure.
Required attribute supports the validation and identification of the healthcare provider and his/her given privileges
An act that is intended to result in new information about a subject. In this instance, regarding restrictions to practice for a specified healthcare provider.
Supports the business requirement to provide information about a healthcare provider where privileges have been restricted.
Mandatory attribute supports the validation and identification of the healthcare provider and his/her given privileges
The value identifying the specific privilege and/or restrictions on those privileges
Populated attribute supports the validation and identification of the healthcare provider and his/her given privileges

This role describes specific qualifications that may be held the provider as a result of training or experience, but having no legal force. Example: a medical degree or diploma. The current model does not include role attributes such as name, addr and telecom because there are no known use cases in this domain where this role is contactable.
Roleclass required to provide additional information for the person responsible for providing healthcare services

If Expertise or Credentials are included in the message, then Role Effective Date Must Exist
Mandatory attribute supports the identification of the healthcare provider credentials

A role played by a place at which services may be provided. The RIM defines two specializations of service delivery location: 1. incidental service delivery location - A role played by a place at which health care services may be provided without prior designation or authorization and 2. dedicated service delivery location - A role played by a place that is intended to house the provision of services. Scoper is the Entity (typically Organization) that provides these services. This is not synonymous with "ownership". This can be further characterized by a role code of: A)DedicatedClinicalLocationRoleType - A role of a place that further classifies the clinical setting (e.g., cardiology clinic, primary care clinic, rehabilitation hospital, skilled nursing facility) in which care is delivered during an encounter or B)DedicatedNonClinicalLocationRoleType - A role of a place that further classifies the setting in which non-clinical services are delivered. A given physical place can play multiple service delivery location roles each with its own attributes. For example, a Podiatric clinic and Research clinic may meet on alternate days in the same physical location; each clinic uses its own mailing address and telephone number.
Roleclass required to support the identification of the physical location where healthcare services are provided
A unique identifier for the service delivery location.
Required attribute supports the validation and identification of the service delivery location
The code identifying the specific service delivery location
Mandatory attribute supports the validation and identification of the service delivery location

Required attribute supports the validation and identification of the service delivery location
The telecom for the specific service delivery location
Required attribute supports the validation and identification of the service delivery location

Required attribute supports the validation and identification of the service delivery location

This is an optional output control parameter. Sender indicates via coded values which class or class attributes in the response model are to be valued in the response. By site agreement codes can be based upon local object model, or alternatively, the classes and attributes from the query response model, as in the example below. Example: requestor wants provider identifier, name and service delivery location data returned so ResponseObject is valued as follows:
<ResponseObject><value code="HealthCareProvider.id"/></ResponseObject>
<ResponseObject><value code="PrincipalPerson.name"/></ResponseObject>
<ResponseObject><value code="ServiceDeliveryLocation"/></ResponseObject>

Utilized to support cases when a source or consumer (such as a Health Authority) wants only specific information about a given set of providers. For example, a HA might want to know all the Work Locations for a given provider type, and wouldn't want to receive all information. The type of information expected in the response is provided via the response object.
Supports the business request to be able to specify expected response to this query
Outlines the values expected to be received by this query
Populated attribute provides tremendous value in giving the organization issuing the query the flexibility to request particular items in the response.

A record of something that is being done, has been done, can be done, or is intended or requested to be done. Acts connect to Entities in their Roles through Participations and connect to other Acts through ActRelationships. Participations are the authors, performers and other responsible parties as well as subjects and beneficiaries (which includes tools and material used in the performance of the act, which are also subjects). The moodCode distinguishes between Acts that are meant as factual records, vs. records of intended or ordered services, and the other modalities in which act can appear.

Acts are the pivot of the RIM; all domain information and processes are represented primarily in Acts. Any profession or business, including healthcare, is primarily constituted of intentional and occasionally non-intentional actions, performed and recorded by responsible actors. An Act-instance is a record of such an action.

documentation.businessName: Act Definition or Event Name Effective Time
documentation.p: Effective Time with regard to the act involved
Required attribute indicating effective time of this act

The role class, assigned entity, captures the critical information of the provider playing the role of interest. This includes an identifier for the role, mailing address, phone number, and the time within which the role is played (may be open ended). The scooping organization, which may be omitted if not needed, provides the organizational context for the entity that actually plays the role. For example, the role scoper will normally be the party that assigns the identifier for the role.

Supports business requirement to provide additional information regarding the jurisdication within the scoping organization exists.
The code identifying the specific Territorial Authority
Mandatory attribute supports the validation and identification of the healthcare provider

A record of something that is being done, has been done, can be done, or is intended or requested to be done. Acts connect to Entities in their Roles through Participations and connect to other Acts through ActRelationships. Participations are the authors, performers and other responsible parties as well as subjects and beneficiaries (which includes tools and material used in the performance of the act, which are also subjects). The moodCode distinguishes between Acts that are meant as factual records, vs. records of intended or ordered services, and the other modalities in which act can appear.

Acts are the pivot of the RIM; all domain information and processes are represented primarily in Acts. Any profession or business, including healthcare, is primarily constituted of intentional and occasionally non-intentional actions, performed and recorded by responsible actors. An Act-instance is a record of such an action.

documentation.businessName: Act Definition or Event Name Effective Time
documentation.p: Effective Time with regard to the act involved
Required attribute indicating effective time of this act

The role class, assigned entity, captures the critical information of the provider playing the role of interest. This includes an identifier for the role, mailing address, phone number, and the time within which the role is played (may be open ended). The scooping organization, which may be omitted if not needed, provides the organizational context for the entity that actually plays the role. For example, the role scoper will normally be the party that assigns the identifier for the role.
Roleclass required to provide additional information for the person responsible for providing healthcare services within a specific healthcare setting
Identifies specific functional role that a provider may play within an organization.
Required attribute supports the identification of the healthcare provider
The code identifying the specific functional role.
Mandatory attribute supports the identification of the healthcare provider
The providers name pertaining to the specific functional role.
Required attribute supports the identification of the healthcare provider
RoleClass to support birthplace of Principal Person
Supports business requirement to provide birthplace of Principal Person
Principal person's address at time of birth
If Birthplace is included in the message, then Address is Expected to Exist.
Mandatory attribute supports the identification of the healthcare provider
This roles the specific Healthcare provider role such as a Physician, Nurse or other type of caregivers.
Roleclass required to support the identification of person responsible for providing healthcare services
A unique identifier for a provider in a specific healthcare role.
Mandatory attribute supports the identification of the healthcare provider
The code identifying the specific healthcare provider role.
Mandatory attribute supports the identification of the healthcare provider
The providers name pertaining to the specific healthcare provider role.
Required attribute supports the identification of the healthcare provider
Jurisdiction within which the scoping organization exists
Supports the business requirement to provide additional information about which jurisdication the scoping organization exists in.
A character value that represents the Canadian provincial or territorial geographical area within which the Provider is operating.
If Jurisdiction is included in the message, then Territorial Authority Type is Expected to Exist.
Populated attribute supports the validation and identification of the healthcare provider
Information about what language(s) should be used to communicate with the focal person can be sent in the LanguageCommunication class.
Supports the business requirement to identify languages used by client for the purposes of communication
A code indicating the language of communication
Mandatory attribute conveying the expected language message elements are to be transmitted in
Indicates the healthcare provider's ability to communicate in the indicated language i.e. written, spoken, read
Required attribute provides additional information about the healthcare provider's communication skills in a given language

documentation.businessName: Language of Communication Proficiency Level Code
documentation.p: Indicates the proficiency level at which healthcare provider is able to communicate in the indicated language of communication
Required attribute provides additional information about the healthcare provider's communication skills in a given language
Indicates the preferred language for all communications.
Required attribute that supports the business requirement to indicate the preferred language for all communications.
The scoping organization for the specified role class
Supports the requirement to supply additional information regarding the assigning Organization of the specified RoleClass
Identification of playing entity is required (0..1) to support the case in which information directly related to the playing party is not needed.
Provides additional information about the person playing the role of Healthcare Provider
A unique identifier for the person who may play various healthcare provider roles. This identifier is specific to the person not their roles.
Required attribute supports the identification of the healthcare provider
The persons name independent of any role they may play.
If Principal Person is included in the message, then Person Name Must Exist.
Required attribute supports the identification of the healthcare provider
The principal persons gender.
If Principal Person is included in the message, then Person Gender is Expected to Exist.
Required attribute supports the identification of the healthcare provider
The principal persons date of birth.
If Principal Person is included in the message, then Prinicpal Person Date of Birth is Expected to Exist.
Required attribute supports the identification of the healthcare provider
An indication that the principal person is deceased.
Required attribute supports the identification of the healthcare provider
The date and time that a healthcare provider's death occurred.
Required attribute supports verification of death from official source such as Vital Statistics.

A record of something that is being done, has been done, can be done, or is intended or requested to be done. In this instance it is a description of the privilege associated with the specified healthcare providers' practice
Supports the business requirement to identify privileges associated with the specified healthcare provider
Unique identifier for the restriction.
Populated attribute supports the validation and identification of the healthcare provider and his/her given privileges
Effective date of the restriction.
If Restrictions to Practice are included in the message, then Effective Date Must Exist
Populated attribute supports the validation and identification of the healthcare provider and his/her given privileges
An act that is intended to result in new information about a subject. In this instance, regarding restrictions to practice for a specified healthcare provider.
Supports the business requirement to provide information about a healthcare provider where privileges have been restricted.
The code identifying the specific privilege and/or restrictions on those privileges
Populated attribute supports the validation and identification of the healthcare provider and his/her given privileges
The value identifying the specific privilege and/or restrictions on those privileges
Populated attribute supports the validation and identification of the healthcare provider and his/her given privileges

This role describes specific qualifications that may be held the provider as a result of training or experience, but having no legal force. Example: a medical degree or diploma. The current model does not include role attributes such as name, addr and telecom because there are no known use cases in this domain where this role is contactable.
Roleclass required to provide additional information for the person responsible for providing healthcare services
Unique identifier for the Expertise or Credential.
Required attribute supports the identification of the healthcare provider credentials
A code for the degree or educational rank that the credential specifies. May also apply to an Expertise type.
Required attribute supports the identification of the healthcare provider credentials

documentation.businessName: Expertise or Credentials Role Effective Date
documentation.p: The effective date of the provider expertise or credentials in the healthcare provider role.
If Expertise or Credentials are included in the message, then Role Effective Date Must Exist
Required attribute supports the identification of the healthcare provider credentials

A role played by a place at which services may be provided. The RIM defines two specializations of service delivery location: 1. incidental service delivery location - A role played by a place at which health care services may be provided without prior designation or authorization and 2. dedicated service delivery location - A role played by a place that is intended to house the provision of services. Scoper is the Entity (typically Organization) that provides these services. This is not synonymous with "ownership". This can be further characterized by a role code of: A)DedicatedClinicalLocationRoleType - A role of a place that further classifies the clinical setting (e.g., cardiology clinic, primary care clinic, rehabilitation hospital, skilled nursing facility) in which care is delivered during an encounter or B)DedicatedNonClinicalLocationRoleType - A role of a place that further classifies the setting in which non-clinical services are delivered. A given physical place can play multiple service delivery location roles each with its own attributes. For example, a Podiatric clinic and Research clinic may meet on alternate days in the same physical location; each clinic uses its own mailing address and telephone number.
Roleclass required to support the identification of the physical location where healthcare services are provided
A unique identifier for the service delivery location.
Mandatory attribute supports the validation and identification of the service delivery location
RoleClass necessary to support the Jurisdiction within which the scoping organization exists
Supports business requirement to provide additional information regarding the jurisdication within the scoping organization exists.
The code identifying the specific Territorial Authority
Populated attribute supports the validation and identification of the healthcare provider
Identifies the action that resulted in this message being sent.
There may be constraints on the usage of the effectiveTime and reasonCode attributes in the definition of the interaction or the trigger events which are conveyed with this wrapper.
Key to understanding what action a message represents.
A unique identifier for this particular event assigned by the system in which the event occurred.
Identifier needs to be persisted by receiving applications, except for queries (queries cannot be retracted or undone).
Allows the event to be referenced (for undos) and also indicates whether multiple interactions were caused by the same triggering event. Also used for audit purposes.
Identifies the trigger event that occurred.
This is mandatory because it is essential to understanding the meaning of the event.
Describes the status of the control act, which is always complete (it happened).
Required for completeness of specification.
Indicates the time the event (e.g. query, change, activation) should begin and occasionally when it should end.

The time an event becomes effective may differ from the time the event is recorded (i.e. it may be in the future or the past). For events such as 'suspend', an intended end date may also be indicated.
Identifies why this specific message interaction (e.g. query, activation request, modification request) occurred.
The domain associated with this attribute will vary for each interaction and will be noted as part of the interaction description.
Allows identifying a reason for a specific action, such as 'reason for hold' or 'reason for accessing information'.
Unique number for the query to be continued.
Links to the query for which continuation is desired. Needed to ensure that the query is not re-executed, as the results may have changed. As a result, the attribute is mandatory.
Indicates the record number at which to start the returned result set.
Indicates what point the query should continue from and is therefore mandatory.
Indicates how many records should be returned for this query.
Allows an application to control the number of returned records. If not specified, the EHR may apply a default limit.
Indicates the person responsible for the event that caused this message.
Critical for auditing and for validating permissions and therefore mandatory.
Value should always be AUT

The time the person responsible for the event made the decision for it to occur. This may be different than the time the change became effective. (E.g. If a provider decides today to put a prescription on hold starting next Tuesday, the time of creation would be today and the change effective period would be next Tuesday.)
This date can be back-dated.
The time a change is made is a critical piece of audit information and is therefore mandatory.
Indicates how the person who recorded the event became aware of it.. E.g. Verbal, written, fax, etc.
May have ramifications for the audit trail and reliability of the information.
Indicates the formal digital signature of the message content.
Digital signatures may be needed for authentication of message content. The attribute is marked as optional because it is not yet clear whether there is a use-case for this, or where it will be used.

This is a messaging artifact used by HL7 to allow the time, signiture and method to be captured when the author is not sent. This will happen in circumstances where the author information is sent as part of the authentication token.
Conveys an authentication token associated with the event.
The token may represent one or all of the following concepts: author, dataEnterer, responsibleParty, location and dataEntryLocation.
Conveys information related to the individuals and/or locations involved with the action in situations where the authentication happens on a one-time basis rather than on a per-message basis.
An authorization token expressed as a GUID.
The Authorization token may represent the concepts of author, data enterer, supervisor (responsible party), responsible location and/or data entry location.
GUIDs are an effective way of conveying a temporary authentication token
An authentication token expressed as a non-GUID string.
The Authorization token may represent the concepts of author, data enterer, supervisor (responsible party), responsible location and/or data entry location.
Some systems may choose to use a hashcode or other approach to token construction.
A care composition is a record, which summarizes the events that happened during care including who is responsible for the care provided.
Examples include encounters, health condition (episode)-based collections and general care-based collections such as "gynecological care".
Allows linking records to encounters, condition and care-based compositions. Useful for searching and navigation of the patient's record.
Identifies the action that resulted in this message being sent.
There may be constraints on the usage of the effectiveTime and reasonCode attributes in the definition of the interaction or the trigger events which are conveyed with this wrapper.
Key to understanding what action a message represents.
A unique identifier for this particular event assigned by the system in which the event occurred.
Identifier needs to be persisted by receiving applications, except for queries (queries cannot be retracted or undone).
Allows the event to be referenced (for undos) and also indicates whether multiple interactions were caused by the same triggering event. Also used for audit purposes.
Identifies the trigger event that occurred.
This is mandatory because it is essential to understanding the meaning of the event.
Describes the status of the control act, which is always complete (it happened).
Required for completeness of specification.
Indicates the time the event (e.g. query, change, activation) should begin and occasionally when it should end.

The time an event becomes effective may differ from the time the event is recorded (i.e. it may be in the future or the past). For events such as 'suspend', an intended end date may also be indicated.
Identifies why this specific message interaction (e.g. query, activation request, modification request) occurred.
The domain associated with this attribute will vary for each interaction and will be noted as part of the interaction description.
Allows identifying a reason for a specific action, such as 'reason for hold' or 'reason for accessing information'.

Indicates the person responsible for entering the query into the system. Used when different from the person responsible for the request (author). For example, physician requests administrative assistant to print off a patient's medication profile.
This should only be specified if different from the author.
Important for audit information and determining permissions.
The association is optional because in some jurisdictions this information will be conveyed as part of the authentication token.
Indicates the location where the record of this event was entered.
This should only be specified if different from the location where the event was authored.
Indicates a potential location for written records, and may also be important for authentication purposes.
The association is optional because in some jurisdictions this information will be conveyed as part of the authentication token.
Indicates the service delivery location where the event occurred.
Indicates where paper records may be located, and may be important to determining authorization.
The association is optional because in some jurisdictions this information will be conveyed as part of the authentication token.
Identifies the authentication token that references information about the people and/or places responsible for the event.
Some systems perform centralized authentication of providers and/or locations. The association is optional because not all systems will make use of a token-based authentication process.
Unique number for this particular query.
Needed to allow continuation of queries and linking of query requests and responses and therefore mandatory.
This allows the sender to indicate to the receiver that this query should follow an expedited processing flow.

Intended to convey the requested 'packaging' of query results. This attribute does not affect which rows are selected by the query, just the manner in which they are returned. For example, a batch file containing responses, a response message containing multiple payloads, or a stream of response messages (notifications) each identifying itself as a response to a query request.
The number of response item repetitions that should be included in the initial response.

If not specified, the default behavior is to return all repetitions. However the recipient of a query may always choose to limit the quantity returned to be less than the number requested. Regardless of the number specified here, the number of rows returned will never exceed the number of matching rows based on the query parameters.
There may be a very large number of matching rows. To manage communication bandwidth, a limited set may initially be returned with further data retrieved by using query continuations.
Defines the units associated with the magnitude of the maximum size limit of a query response that can be accepted by the requesting application.
Needed to quantify the types of records requested to be returned in the query.

Associated patient record for which this message applies. Record target can be one of either identified patient (id, name, gender, date of birth), indeterminate patient (name, gender, date of birth) or a patient token (suggesting client identity).
Choice of Patient CMET is as follows:
COCT_MT050201CA 'identified' when supporting Patient Session Tokens.
COCT_MT050207CA 'informational' when passing through non Client- Registry patient for PHS or similar processing.
COCT_MT050202CA 'identified-confirmable' otherwise.

Inferring patient identity opens up the potential for privacy breach through the mis-keying of identifiers. Also, inclusion of patient identity simplifies logging, processing and application of data access constraints such as masking and consent. Finally, patient id is required to support both EHR Index (record and update) and Patient Profile Summary query (list).
Patient identity is key to successful operation of the EHR.
A bare identifier exposes the patient to potential privacy violation.
Allows for the trail of responsibility for the action. The association is optional because in some jurisdictions, the supervisor may be conveyed by he authentication token.
Important for audit information and determining permissions.
The association is optional because in some jurisdictions this information will be conveyed as part of the authentication token
This is the list of clinical and business issues that have been detected and/or managed involving the current action.
Any trigger event can result in errors or may allow for errors to be overridden or managed.
Information pertaining to a patient's agreement/acceptance to have his/her clinical information electronically stored and shared.

This will usually only be populated for queries, but could be used for updates if a jurisdiction requires consent before recording information in the EHR (e.g. consent to participate in electronic data exchange).
Note: keywords canot be passed from one application to another via the EHR (e.g. prescriber to dispenser via a Drug Information System).
Provides authorization to record and/or view patient information.

Indicates the consent or keyword used to authorize access or update, including a reason for access; May also be used to override access restriction to the information ('break the glass') on a message by message basis.
May be required on a Prescription Request to indicate a keyword for drug utilization processing.
Indicates the person responsible for the event that caused this message.
Critical for auditing and for validating permissions and therefore mandatory.
Value should always be AUT

This date can be back-dated.

Identifies the query being acknowledged
Allows linking of a response back to the request that triggered it and is therefore mandatory. Particularly useful when responses are deferred or queued.
Indicates whether the query was successful or not.
Used to control receiver logic and is therefore mandatory.
Identifies the total number of rows identified that matched the query.
Indicates the overall size of the result-set and is therefore mandatory. Particularly useful when only part of the result set is actually returned.
Identifies the number of rows returned as part of this particular query response.
Provides a quick overview of the results of the query and is therefore mandatory.
Indicates the number of rows that still exist after the last row returned in this response.
Identifies how much data remains to be queried and is therefore mandatory.
Unique number for this particular query.
Needed to allow continuation of queries and linking of query requests and responses and therefore mandatory.

Finally, patient id is required to support both EHR Index (record and update) and Patient Profile Summary query (list).

This is the list of clinical and business issues that have been detected and/or managed involving the current action.
Any trigger event can result in errors or may allow for errors to be overridden or managed.
Indicates the item(s) being acted upon by this trigger event.
Will be mandatory in wrappers with payload messages, otherwise not present.
If there are multiple subject items, the changes to all of them must be either accepted or rejected as a single action. I.e. One trigger event = 1 unit of work.
Provides information about the thing being created, modified or removed.
Indicates whether or not objects of the trigger event are to be cascaded to the payload.

If true, associations in the parent act are conducted across the ActRelationship to the message payload (act). Conduction for each association is specifically indicated by each associations' contextControlCode value.

In other words, if the "subject" act relationship has contextConductionInd=true; THEN the subjectOf association is carried (to the regsitrationEvent act) according to the subjectOf.contextControlCode (AP = propogate to the reg event and add to any subject(s) (issues) already present).
Cascading of trigger event objects allows different messages to employ consistent and common objects.
Attribute is mandatory to ensure that cascading will be specified one way or another.
Information pertaining to a patient's agreement/acceptance to have his/her clinical information electronically stored and shared.

This will usually only be populated for queries, but could be used for updates if a jurisdiction requires consent before recording information in the EHR (e.g. consent to participate in electronic data exchange).

Indicates whether the query was successful or not.
Used to control receiver logic and is therefore mandatory.
Identifies the total number of rows identified that matched the query.
Indicates the overall size of the result-set and is therefore mandatory. Particularly useful when only part of the result set is actually returned.
Identifies the number of rows returned as part of this particular query response.
Provides a quick overview of the results of the query and is therefore mandatory.
Indicates the number of rows that still exist after the last row returned in this response.
Identifies how much data remains to be queried and is therefore mandatory.
Unique number for this particular query.
Needed to allow continuation of queries and linking of query requests and responses and therefore mandatory.
This allows the sender to indicate to the receiver that this query should follow an expedited processing flow.

Intended to convey the 'packaging' of query results. This attribute does not affect which rows are selected by the query, just the manner in which they are returned. For example, a batch file containing responses, a response message containing multiple payloads, or a stream of response messages (notifications) each identifying itself as a response to a query request.
The number of response item repetitions that should be included in the initial response.

If not specified, the default behavior is to return all repetitions. However the recipient of a query may always choose to limit the quantity returned to be less than the number requested. Regardless of the number specified here, the number of rows returned will never exceed the number of matching rows based on the query parameters.
There may be a very large number of matching rows. To manage communication bandwidth, a limited set may initially be returned with further data retrieved by using query continuations.
Defines the units associated with the magnitude of the maximum size limit of a query response that can be accepted by the requesting application.
Needed to quantify the types of records requested to be returned in the query.
This is the list of clinical and business issues that have been detected and/or managed involving the current action.
Any trigger event can result in errors or may allow for errors to be overridden or managed.
Indicates the item(s) being acted upon by this trigger event.
Will be mandatory in wrappers with payload messages, otherwise not present.
If there are multiple subject items, the changes to all of them must be either accepted or rejected as a single action. I.e. One trigger event = 1 unit of work.
Provides information about the thing being created, modified or removed.
Indicates whether or not objects of the trigger event are to be cascaded to the payload.

If true, associations in the parent act are conducted across the ActRelationship to the message payload (act). Conduction for each association is specifically indicated by each associations' contextControlCode value.

In other words, if the "subject" act relationship has contextConductionInd=true; THEN the subjectOf association is carried (to the regsitrationEvent act) according to the subjectOf.contextControlCode (AP = propogate to the reg event and add to any subject(s) (issues) already present).
Cascading of trigger event objects allows different messages to employ consistent and common objects.
Attribute is mandatory to ensure that cascading will be specified one way or another.
Information pertaining to a patient's agreement/acceptance to have his/her clinical information electronically stored and shared.

This will usually only be populated for queries, but could be used for updates if a jurisdiction requires consent before recording information in the EHR (e.g. consent to participate in electronic data exchange).
Note: keywords canot be passed from one application to another via the EHR (e.g. prescriber to dispenser via a Drug Information System).
Provides authorization to record and/or view patient information.

Indicates the consent or keyword used to authorize access or update, including a reason for access; May also be used to override access restriction to the information ('break the glass') on a message by message basis.
May be required on a Prescription Request to indicate a keyword for drug utilization processing.
Indicates that the consent was provided by the patient or representative.
Consent can be provided by the patient or representative or be overridden by a provider. It is important to know which occurred for audit purposes.
Indicates whether the patient's consent is written or verbal.
Verbal consents may trigger a higher level of auditing.
Indicates that information access was approved by a provider rather than a patient. I.e. This is an override rather than an actual consent.
Clinical circumstances may demand that a patient's information be accessed without consent to ensure patient safety.
Indicates the type of information access consented to
Provides details about the consent
Information pertaining to a patient's agreement/acceptance to have his/her clinical information electronically stored and shared.
Provides authorization to record and/or view patient information.
If code is INFA, then InformDefinition must be present, otherwise it must be absent
One and only one of author1 (Consenter) and author2 (Provider) must be specified
If author2 (provider) is specified, reasonCode must be specified
A unique identifier for a specific consent for a patient.
Provides a traceable audit link between a physical consent form and its electronic record
Indicates the type of consent being given: Information access or Information maintenance.
Distinguishes what type of consent is being dealt with and is therefore mandatory.
If true, indicates that consent has explicitly *not* been given.
Primarily applies for global "participation" consent, when there is a need to track whether the patient has consented, not consented, or has not recorded a decision.
Because not all jurisdictions will track "participation" consent, this attribute is optional. In jurisdictions where it is supported, the element must always be valued as either true or false.
Must be either not present or non-null.
Indicates the time that the consent will expire. 'Low' is effective time and 'High' is end time.
Most consents are not open-ended, to ensure the patient retains a level of control
Indicates a reason for overriding a patient's consent rules or accessing information without consent.
Important for audit purposes
Indicates that consent was granted by the patient themselves
Allows assertion of who issued the consent.
Describes the type of information access being consented to.
Allows fine-grained control over the types of information access is granted to and who is granted access.
Identifies the beneficiary of the consent as being a Provider or Service Location.
Indicates who is being authorized to receive the information, and is therefore populated.
The type of patient information that can be accessed or modified.

Different consents may need access to different types of patient information (e.g. demographics, medications, allergies, lab results). Understanding the type of information the consent applies to is critical to controlling access, and therefore the attribute is mandatory.
Indicates that revision to the keyword was requested by the patient or representative.
Indicates who is responsible for changing the keyword, and is therefore mandatory
Indicate the keyword associated with a particular consent.
Allows patients to change their keyword. If explicitly set to null, removes the keyword for the identified record types. Because of this, the attribute is set to 'populated'.
Information pertaining to a patient's secret password used to control access to his/her health information.
Allows a patient to control access to their health information. Provides authorization for providers to view patient information.
Indicates that the keyword was changed by the patient themselves.
Sometimes keywords are changed by the patient, sometimes by a patient representative.
The type of patient information that can be accessed or modified. Examples are: demographics, medications, lab, DI, etc
The keyword revisioning process may also involve revising the list of information types covered by the keyword.

Different keywords may be needed to access different types of patient information (e.g. demographics, medications, allergies, lab results). Understanding the type of information the keyword applies to is critical, and therefore the attribute is mandatory.
Indicates the categories of information governed whose access is governed by the keyword.
Allows the patient to selectively apply diffent keywords to different information categories.
At least one information category must be identified, thus this participation is mandatory.
This interaction occurs after a new person is added to a person registry. An informer sends to a tracker a copy of the new person record.
This interaction occurs after when a person record is to be revised in a person registry.
This interaction sends a query to a Person Registry requesting demographic information for a specific person identifier.
This interaction sends a response from a Person Registry with demographic information for a specific person identifier.
This interaction sends a query to a Person Registry requesting a list of candidates that match a particular set of person demographics.

This interaction returns a list of candidates from a Person Registry that match a particular set of person demographics. The response may also include a score indicating the probability of match for each candidate.
This interaction sends a query to a Person Registry requesting all other identifiers associated with a specific person identifier.
This interaction returns a set of identifiers associated with a particular person identifier in a Person Registry.
This interaction occurs when a new person is to be added to a person registry.
A person registry accepts a request to add a record and responds back to the requesting application. The payload contains the identifier assigned to the new person record.

person registry rejects a request to add a record and responds back to the requesting application. The reason for the rejection is returned as a Detected Issue in the Master File / Reg Notif. Control Act, Role Subject wrapper.
This interaction occurs after information about a person is revised in a person registry. An informer sends to a tracker updated person information.
A person registry accepts a request to revise an existing record and responds back to the requesting application. The revised person record is sent in the payload.

A person registry rejects a request to revise an existing record and responds back to the requesting application. The reason for the rejection is returned as a Detected Issue in the Master File / Reg Notif. Control Act, Role Subject wrapper
This interaction occurs after an erroneously entered person record is nullified in a person registry. An informer sends to a tracker enough information to identify the nullified record.
This interaction is used to request that a new provider record be added to a provider registry system.
This interaction notifies of a new provider registration.
TThis interaction is used to request that a provider record be updated within a provider registry system.
This interaction is used to send a notification that a provider record has been updated in a provider registry system. No response is expected from the recipient system.

This interaction is used to request details about a provider. It is expected that the receiving application will respond with the Provider Details Query Response containing the requested information from the provider registry system.
This interaction is used to respond to an Provider Details Query interaction and will contain the requested records from the provider registry system.
This interaction is used to respond to a Provider Associated Identifiers Query interaction and will contain the requested records from the provider registry system.
